cisco_ios_troubleshooting_commands.description: Displays the system hardware configuration, software version, and configuration files. Crucial for checking uptime and the IOS version.
Shows the currently active configuration on the device. Use 'show running-config | section <protocol/interface>' to narrow the output.
Provides detailed status and statistics for all interfaces, including line protocol status, encapsulation, and traffic counters.
Gives a quick, one-line summary of the status of each interface, including its IP address and operational state (up/down).
Displays the IP routing table. Used to verify static routes, routing protocol entries, and overall L3 reachability.
Shows the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) table, which maps Layer 3 IP addresses to Layer 2 MAC addresses.
Displays the Layer 2 MAC address forwarding table on a switch. Essential for troubleshooting L2 connectivity issues.
Shows directly connected Cisco devices using the Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP), revealing local device IDs and port information.
A vendor-neutral alternative to CDP, LLDP (Link Layer Discovery Protocol) shows directly connected network devices.
Displays the device's log messages, which are invaluable for identifying errors, interface flaps, and security events.
Provides a summary of configured dynamic routing protocols (like OSPF, EIGRP, BGP), including timers, networks, and neighbor information.
Shows the status of the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) for a specific VLAN, including the root bridge, port roles, and status.
Displays the active Internet Key Exchange (IKE) Security Associations (SAs) for IPsec VPN tunnels (Phase 1).
Shows the IPsec Security Associations (SAs), including packets encrypted and decrypted, for active VPN tunnels (Phase 2).
Tests basic network connectivity to a destination IP address or hostname using ICMP echo requests.
Identifies the Layer 3 path (hops) to a destination, helping to locate routing loops or points of failure.
